clean_story:
Sticky bonds. Holds what breaks apart.
The word glue comes from the Old French glu, meaning "birdlime"—a sticky sap once used to trap birds.


Glue is a liquid that hardens into an invisible force, locking materials together.
Early versions came from boiling animal hides or fish bones—like turning scraps into a second skin for broken pottery.
Modern glues use polymers: tiny chains that tangle like vines, gripping surfaces at a microscopic level.
Super Glue (cyanoacrylate) bonds in seconds when moisture triggers its molecules to link like a zipper.
Epoxy, a two-part glue, mixes resin and hardener—like cake batter needing both flour and eggs to set.
Without glue, airplanes wouldn’t seal their wings, smartphones would rattle apart, and bandages wouldn’t stick to knees.
Yet its strength depends on the surface: smooth glass resists, while rough wood gives it teeth to grip.
Adhesives that mimic gecko feet.
Bio-glues for surgical wounds.
The chemistry of what refuses to let go.
